<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two novel coordination polymers incorporating mercury(II) iodide, [Hg (tmp)I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (tmp=4,4′-trimethylene dipyridine) and [Hg(azobpy)I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (azobpy=3,3′-azobispyridine), have been synthesized via the self-assembly reaction in solution. Their structures were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first 1D wave-shaped adduct containing HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a 3D supramolecular framework constructed from HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–azobpy zigzag chains linked mutually through Hg⋯I interaction. The optical limiting effects were studied by <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan technology with an 8 ns-pulsed laser at 532 nm. Their limiting thresholds were determined to be 0.8 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 0.4 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, which are comparable to those of many heterothiometallates.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two novel coordination polymers incorporating mercury(II) iodide, [Hg (tmp)I2] n  (1) (tmp=4,4'-trimethylene dipyridine) and [Hg(azobpy)I2] n  (2) (azobpy=3,3'-azobispyridine), have been synthesized via the self-assembly reaction in solution. Their structures were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Complex 1 is the first 1D wave-shaped adduct containing HgI2. Complex 2 is a 3D supramolecular framework constructed from HgI2-azobpy zigzag chains linked mutually through Hg⋯I interaction. The optical limiting effects were studied by Z-scan technology with an 8 ns-pulsed laser at 532 nm. Their limiting thresholds were determined to be 0.8 J cm-2 for 1 and 0.4 J cm-2 for 2, which are comparable to those of many heterothiometallates.

<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ázobpy)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a wave-shaped polymeric structure originated from <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> conformation of the tmp ligands. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possesses zigzag structures interacting each other via Hg⋯I bond to form a 3D supramolecule structure. Their optical limiting threshold was determined to be 0.8 and 0.4 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>, which is comparable to those of many heterothiometallates.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Reaction of HgI2 with 4,4'-trimethylene dipyridine (tmp) or 3,3'-azobispyridine in THF gives two adducts [HgI2(tmp)] n  (1) and [HgI2(ázobpy)] n  (2). 1 has a wave-shaped polymeric structure originated from anti-anti conformation of the tmp ligands. 2 possesses zigzag structures interacting each other via Hg⋯I bond to form a 3D supramolecule structure. Their optical limiting threshold was determined to be 0.8 and 0.4 J cm-2, which is comparable to those of many heterothiometallates.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Nonlinear optical (NLO) materials have attracted much attention because of their potentials derived from the optical limiting properties . One important direction has been, and continues to be, the research for new compounds and, therewith new or unusual properties: lower values of third-order NLO limiting threshold in short-wavelength region are key criteria in screening novel NLO materials . On the other hand, the use of 4,4'-bipyridyl-based ligands in the construction of supramolecular inorganic/organic hybrid materials has enjoyed significant success. It has been found that some coordination polymers show interesting NLO properties . By modifying building blocks with proper type and distribution of binding sites, ordered network structure with excellent optical characteristics can be deliberately generated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nonlinear optical (NLO) materials have attracted much attention because of their potentials derived from the optical limiting properties . One important direction has been, and continues to be, the research for new compounds and, therewith new or unusual properties: lower values of third-order NLO limiting threshold in short-wavelength region are key criteria in screening novel NLO materials . On the other hand, the use of 4,4'-bipyridyl-based ligands in the construction of supramolecular inorganic/organic hybrid materials has enjoyed significant success. It has been found that some coordination polymers show interesting NLO properties . By modifying building blocks with proper type and distribution of binding sites, ordered network structure with excellent optical characteristics can be deliberately generated.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The idea behind our choice of exploring HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> complexes with bipyridyl ligands is based on two important experimental facts that distinguish this kind of adducts from common complexes. (1) Mercuric iodide, on the basis of its physical and electronic properties, has recently been the focus of many studies because of its important utility in the fields such as optical detector  and superconducting materials . Its most distinguishing feature, high density (6.3 g cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>) and high average atomic numbers of the constituent elements (80 and 53), result in a very large photoelectric effect and a high full-energy peak efficiency, especially at higher γ-ray energies . In addition, as the Group 12 metal complexes, the constituent elements, mercury together with the Group 17 iodine are relatively heavy, more sublevels can be introduced into the energy merarcncy which permits more spin-allowed excited-state to excited-state transitions to take place. That is to say, a heavy-atom effect may bring better NLO effects . (2) In certain cases, polymeric aggregation could result in enhancement of optical limiting effect (OL) . Our recent studies on the relative coordination chemistry show that HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adducts exhibit different structural characteristics comparing to the related HgCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and HgBr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adducts . However, because of the limited solubility of HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in common solvents, structure information on its adducts has been derived mainly on the basis of IR data from powder samples . We have found that typical convenient solvent for the generation of HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adduct arrays are tetrahydrofuran, which may easily dissolve MI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (M=Zn, Cd, Hg) and further to react with various bipyridyl-based ligands, resulting in several interesting polymeric frameworks. In the present work we have used the solubility of the HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in THF to prepare two novel adducts of bipyridyl-based ligands. The [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (tmp=4,4′-trimethylene dipyridine) is a wave-shaped structure based on <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> configuration of tmp ligands. The adduct [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(azobpy)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (azobpy=3,3′-azobipyridine) possesses polymeric zigzag chain structures interacted with weak electronic interaction. The optical limiting effects of coordination polymers were firstly investigated and reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The idea behind our choice of exploring HgI2 complexes with bipyridyl ligands is based on two important experimental facts that distinguish this kind of adducts from common complexes. (1) Mercuric iodide, on the basis of its physical and electronic properties, has recently been the focus of many studies because of its important utility in the fields such as optical detector  and superconducting materials . Its most distinguishing feature, high density (6.3 g cm-3) and high average atomic numbers of the constituent elements (80 and 53), result in a very large photoelectric effect and a high full-energy peak efficiency, especially at higher γ-ray energies . In addition, as the Group 12 metal complexes, the constituent elements, mercury together with the Group 17 iodine are relatively heavy, more sublevels can be introduced into the energy merarcncy which permits more spin-allowed excited-state to excited-state transitions to take place. That is to say, a heavy-atom effect may bring better NLO effects . (2) In certain cases, polymeric aggregation could result in enhancement of optical limiting effect (OL) . Our recent studies on the relative coordination chemistry show that HgI2 adducts exhibit different structural characteristics comparing to the related HgCl2 and HgBr2 adducts . However, because of the limited solubility of HgI2 in common solvents, structure information on its adducts has been derived mainly on the basis of IR data from powder samples . We have found that typical convenient solvent for the generation of HgI2 adduct arrays are tetrahydrofuran, which may easily dissolve MI2 (M=Zn, Cd, Hg) and further to react with various bipyridyl-based ligands, resulting in several interesting polymeric frameworks. In the present work we have used the solubility of the HgI2 in THF to prepare two novel adducts of bipyridyl-based ligands. The [HgI2(tmp)] n  (tmp=4,4'-trimethylene dipyridine) is a wave-shaped structure based on anti-anti configuration of tmp ligands. The adduct [HgI2(azobpy)] n  (azobpy=3,3'-azobipyridine) possesses polymeric zigzag chain structures interacted with weak electronic interaction. The optical limiting effects of coordination polymers were firstly investigated and reported.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

4,4'-Trimethylene dipyridine and 3,3'-azobispyridine were obtained from Aldrich Chemical Company. All other chemicals were of A.R. Grade and used without further purification.

IR spectra were recorded with a Shimazu IR435 spectrometer in the region of 400-4000 cm-1 with pressed KBr pellets. Carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen analyses were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240C instrument.

Synthesis of [HgI2(tmp)] n  (1)

A methanol solution (10 ml) of tmp (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) was laid carefully above a THF solution (10 ml) of HgI2 (45.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), yellow crystals (20% yield) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained 3 days later. Calc. for C13H14N2HgI2: C, 23.92; H, 2.17; N, 4.29%; IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2942.0(m), 1608.9(vs), 1426.6(s), 1221.5(sh), 1067.3(m), 1010.7(s), 813.7(s), 608.2(m), 514.8(s).

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Crystallographic data for the title compounds were collected using Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the shelxtl program , and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. Crystal data are summarized in detail in  , Selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1 and 2 are put in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Optical limiting measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The optical measurements were performed with linearly polarized 7-ns pulses at 532 nm generated from a frequency-doubled Q-switched Nd:YAG laser, this wavelength is of paramount practical importance in the field of optical limiting as well as design and fabrication of resonance cavities of lasers. The spacial profiles of the pulses were nearly Gussian after a spatial filter was employed. A DMF solution of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was placed in a 1-mm-thick quartz cell for optical limiting measurements. The crystal samples of them are stable toward oxygen, moisture and laser light. The laser pulse was focused into the cells containing the nonlinear medium with a 250-mm focal length lens. The laser beam was divided into two beams. One was used to monitor the incident laser energy meter and the other was focused onto the sample cell. The input and the output energies of the beams were measured with an energy meter (Laser Precision Rjp-735) which were linked to a computer by an IEEE interface . The experimental data were collected utilizing a single shot at a rate of 1 pulse min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to avoid the influence of thermal effect.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Optical limiting measurements

The optical measurements were performed with linearly polarized 7-ns pulses at 532 nm generated from a frequency-doubled Q-switched Nd:YAG laser, this wavelength is of paramount practical importance in the field of optical limiting as well as design and fabrication of resonance cavities of lasers. The spacial profiles of the pulses were nearly Gussian after a spatial filter was employed. A DMF solution of compound 1 or 2 was placed in a 1-mm-thick quartz cell for optical limiting measurements. The crystal samples of them are stable toward oxygen, moisture and laser light. The laser pulse was focused into the cells containing the nonlinear medium with a 250-mm focal length lens. The laser beam was divided into two beams. One was used to monitor the incident laser energy meter and the other was focused onto the sample cell. The input and the output energies of the beams were measured with an energy meter (Laser Precision Rjp-735) which were linked to a computer by an IEEE interface . The experimental data were collected utilizing a single shot at a rate of 1 pulse min-1 to avoid the influence of thermal effect.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis of complexes

The solubility of insoluble salts is crucial for the synthesis of the related complexes. Several strategies have been employed to circumvent this practical problem. The formation of I3  - complex may increase the solubility of iodides greatly via the addition of excesses KI or NaI. In addition, seeking and utilization of appropriate solvent is a regular method. Such as HgI2, we have found that THF is a superior solvent to dissolve it. Its solubility in THF is more than 20 times better than that in ethanol. Single crystals of 1 and 2 were grown by the reaction of bipyridyl-based ligands with the HgI2 in THF. The products are insoluble in common organic solvents and stable in air.

<ce:section-title>Structure description</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains wave-shaped chains constructed by repeating [tmpHgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] units (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The local structure depicts a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry at each metal Hg(II), which is completed by two iodide atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two tmp ligands (). The deviation from tetrahedron is probably due to the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as the iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms . This can be testified by the larger bond angles of IHgI (145.25(3)°) and the smaller NHgN angles (110.4(4)°). All the previous zigzag structures have been ascribed to the following three reasons: (a) the steric effect of the iodide group; (b) the rigidity of bipyridyl-based ligands; (c) the preference of Hg for tetrahedral coordination geometry. However, in adduct <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the flexible trimethylene spacer decreases the rigidity of the chain. So the NHgN angle (110.4(4)°) is larger than those in zigzag structures (83°–98.0°) . The whole tmp ligand exhibits an <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> conformation with variable torsion angles of −170.2° (C3C6C7C8) and −162.3° (C6C7C8C11). The two pyridyl rings are inclined to one another at an angle of 72.7°, respectively. The distance between the pyridine nitrogen atoms (N1N2) of 9.454 Å also conforms to the requirements of this conformation . We can reason that ligand's conformation plays an important role in the formation of this wave-shaped structure. All other bond lengths and angles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are comparable to those in related adducts. In the solid-state structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, these chains extend along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis. Each HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> plane goes through the midpoint of a neighboring tmp ligand from another chain. This alternate stacking eliminate possible formation of Hg⋯(μ-)I bonds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description

Crystal structure of 1 

The crystal of 1 contains wave-shaped chains constructed by repeating [tmpHgI2] units (  ).

The local structure depicts a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry at each metal Hg(II), which is completed by two iodide atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two tmp ligands (). The deviation from tetrahedron is probably due to the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as the iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms . This can be testified by the larger bond angles of IHgI (145.25(3)°) and the smaller NHgN angles (110.4(4)°). All the previous zigzag structures have been ascribed to the following three reasons: (a) the steric effect of the iodide group; (b) the rigidity of bipyridyl-based ligands; (c) the preference of Hg for tetrahedral coordination geometry. However, in adduct 1, the flexible trimethylene spacer decreases the rigidity of the chain. So the NHgN angle (110.4(4)°) is larger than those in zigzag structures (83°-98.0°) . The whole tmp ligand exhibits an anti-anti conformation with variable torsion angles of -170.2° (C3C6C7C8) and -162.3° (C6C7C8C11). The two pyridyl rings are inclined to one another at an angle of 72.7°, respectively. The distance between the pyridine nitrogen atoms (N1N2) of 9.454 Å also conforms to the requirements of this conformation . We can reason that ligand's conformation plays an important role in the formation of this wave-shaped structure. All other bond lengths and angles of 1 are comparable to those in related adducts. In the solid-state structure of 1, these chains extend along b-axis. Each HgI2 plane goes through the midpoint of a neighboring tmp ligand from another chain. This alternate stacking eliminate possible formation of Hg⋯(μ-)I bonds.

<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The crystal structures of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are plotted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The compound is composed of 1D zigzag chains with each Hg bonded to two N-donor bifunctional ligands. The remaining two sites of the Hg atom are occupied by two terminal iodide ligands at a distances of 2.638(2) and 2.644(2) Å. To our knowledge, these values give a pair of shortest HgI lengths among HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adducts. The interatomic distance between metal Hg and donor-N atom is 2.479(1) Å. The above shorter HgI distance and longer HgN distance represent a typical sample for the strong preference of Hg for soft donors (the iodine atoms) and weak preference for N atoms comparing to those reported in other Hg adduct polymers . The greatest angular distortion is also exhibited by the IHgI angle of 148.69(6)° and the NHgN angle of 85.5(5)°. While, the NHgI2 and NHgI1 angles (100.6(2)° and 102.2(2)°, respectively) are among the values of other polymeric adducts. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the azobpy ligands adopt an <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-conformation and the two pyridine rings are parallel. The distance between two azo nitrogen atoms is 1.26(9) Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 2 

The crystal structures of 2 are plotted in  . The compound is composed of 1D zigzag chains with each Hg bonded to two N-donor bifunctional ligands. The remaining two sites of the Hg atom are occupied by two terminal iodide ligands at a distances of 2.638(2) and 2.644(2) Å. To our knowledge, these values give a pair of shortest HgI lengths among HgI2 adducts. The interatomic distance between metal Hg and donor-N atom is 2.479(1) Å. The above shorter HgI distance and longer HgN distance represent a typical sample for the strong preference of Hg for soft donors (the iodine atoms) and weak preference for N atoms comparing to those reported in other Hg adduct polymers . The greatest angular distortion is also exhibited by the IHgI angle of 148.69(6)° and the NHgN angle of 85.5(5)°. While, the NHgI2 and NHgI1 angles (100.6(2)° and 102.2(2)°, respectively) are among the values of other polymeric adducts. In 2, the azobpy ligands adopt an anti-conformation and the two pyridine rings are parallel. The distance between two azo nitrogen atoms is 1.26(9) Å.

<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor> shows that the zigzag chains stack extending along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis with parallel pyridyl planes of alternant every other azobpy ligands. All HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> moieties are located at the peaks or valleys of these zigzag chains. The peak—HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> moieties and valley—HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> moieties constitute two kinds of sheets running parallel with the <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic>-plane, respectively. The distance between neighboring sheets is 6.972 Å. Compared with the different NHgI angles in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains regularly two groups of NHgI angles (102.2(2)° and 100.6(2)°). Interestingly, the I2 atoms with smaller NHgI angle of 100.6(2)° exhibit weak interaction with Hg atoms from neighboring chains (with Hg⋯I2 distance of 4.172 Å). All these Hg⋯I2 weak interactions are involved in the sheets running parallel with the <ce:italic>ac-</ce:italic>plane. It is this different stacking pattern that results in the final 3D supramolecular motif. We think that these Hg⋯I interactions are formed with inevitable reasons. In many 4,4′-bpy adducts when M⋯I interactions strengthen to certain level, that is to say, two halide atoms become μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridges between metal centers, a high dimension appears. This depends on the ligand configuration and metal coordination preference .</ce:para>

All HgI2 moieties are located at the peaks or valleys of these zigzag chains. The peak-HgI2 moieties and valley-HgI2 moieties constitute two kinds of sheets running parallel with the ac-plane, respectively. The distance between neighboring sheets is 6.972 Å. Compared with the different NHgI angles in 1, complex 2 contains regularly two groups of NHgI angles (102.2(2)° and 100.6(2)°). Interestingly, the I2 atoms with smaller NHgI angle of 100.6(2)° exhibit weak interaction with Hg atoms from neighboring chains (with Hg⋯I2 distance of 4.172 Å). All these Hg⋯I2 weak interactions are involved in the sheets running parallel with the ac-plane. It is this different stacking pattern that results in the final 3D supramolecular motif. We think that these Hg⋯I interactions are formed with inevitable reasons. In many 4,4'-bpy adducts when M⋯I interactions strengthen to certain level, that is to say, two halide atoms become μ2-bridges between metal centers, a high dimension appears. This depends on the ligand configuration and metal coordination preference .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Optical limiting effects</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The optical limiting effects of adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG5"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG6"></ce:float-anchor>. The peak fluence for <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan is about 1 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> in ns <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan. The transmittance is normalized to its linear transmittance at low incident fluence. The present two adducts, which have different polymeric skeleton, show a result that the optical limiting capacity of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is obviously better than that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. At very low fluence they respond linearly to the incident light fluence obeying Beer's law. The light transmittance starts to deviate from Beer's law of the linear response when the input light fluence rises to certain values with respect to each polymer. The values of the limiting thresholds are measured as 0.8 and 0.4 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> for adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with saturation fluences transmitted of 0.20 and 0.14 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>, respectively, from the optical limiting experimental data. These values are comparable to the values of many heterothiometallate clusters  Lower limiting threshold and saturation level provide greater safety margin for device protection. Previous study showed that the skeletal structure and constituted metal nuclearity have a strong impact on the NLO properties the clusters. Complexes with higher nuclearity or heavy atoms are expected to have favorable NLO properties . So as far as polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are concerned, the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Optical limiting effects

The optical limiting effects of adducts 1 and 2 are depicted in   . The peak fluence for Z-scan is about 1 J cm-2 in ns Z-scan. The transmittance is normalized to its linear transmittance at low incident fluence. The present two adducts, which have different polymeric skeleton, show a result that the optical limiting capacity of 2 is obviously better than that of 1. At very low fluence they respond linearly to the incident light fluence obeying Beer's law. The light transmittance starts to deviate from Beer's law of the linear response when the input light fluence rises to certain values with respect to each polymer. The values of the limiting thresholds are measured as 0.8 and 0.4 J cm-2 for adducts 1 and 2 with saturation fluences transmitted of 0.20 and 0.14 J cm-2, respectively, from the optical limiting experimental data. These values are comparable to the values of many heterothiometallate clusters  Lower limiting threshold and saturation level provide greater safety margin for device protection. Previous study showed that the skeletal structure and constituted metal nuclearity have a strong impact on the NLO properties the clusters. Complexes with higher nuclearity or heavy atoms are expected to have favorable NLO properties . So as far as polymers 1 and 2 are concerned, the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized and structurally characterized two typical mercury iodide adducts through the rational self-assembly method. The optical limiting effects of coordination polymers were firstly investigated. A synthetic protocol for polymeric iodide adducts was summarized. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 1D wave-shaped coordination polymer. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a 3D supramolecule with coordination polymer chains. The introduction of heavier atoms into complex system may bring good NLO properties for heavy-atom effect. The formation of extended arrays from polymerization can result in enhancement of optical limiting effect.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and structurally characterized two typical mercury iodide adducts through the rational self-assembly method. The optical limiting effects of coordination polymers were firstly investigated. A synthetic protocol for polymeric iodide adducts was summarized. Complex 1 is a 1D wave-shaped coordination polymer. Complex 2 is a 3D supramolecule with coordination polymer chains. The introduction of heavier atoms into complex system may bring good NLO properties for heavy-atom effect. The formation of extended arrays from polymerization can result in enhancement of optical limiting effect.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [HgI2(tmp)] n  (1)

A methanol solution (10 ml) of tmp (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) was laid carefully above a THF solution (10 ml) of HgI2 (45.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), yellow crystals (20% yield) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained 3 days later. Found: C, 23.90; H, 2.10; N, 4.38. Calc. for C13H14N2HgI2: C, 23.92; H, 2.17; N, 4.29%; IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2942.0(m), 1608.9(vs), 1426.6(s), 1221.5(sh), 1067.3(m), 1010.7(s), 813.7(s), 608.2(m), 514.8(s).

Synthesis of [HgI2(azobpy)] n  (2)

A THF solution (10 ml) of 3,3'-azobipyridine (18.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dropwise added into a THF solution (10 ml) of HgI2 (45.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), red crystals (23% yield) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained 5 hrs later. Anal. Calc. for C10H8HgI2N4: C, 18.75; H, 1.26; N, 8.75. Found: C, 18.26; H, 1.33; N, 8.90%. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3052(m), 2362(m), 1596(s), 1475(m), 1428(s), 1253(w), 1195(s), 1122(m), 1096(m), 1043(m), 1021(m), 967(m), 841(w), 820(s), 700(s), 636(s), 548(w), 528(m).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The crystal structures of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are plotted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The compound is composed of 1D zigzag chains with each Hg bonded to two N-donor bifunctional ligands. The remaining two sites of the Hg atom are occupied by two terminal iodide ligands at a distances of 2.638(2) and 2.644(2) Å. To our knowledge, these values give a pair of shortest HgI lengths among HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adducts. The interatomic distance between metal Hg and donor-N atom is 2.479(1) Å. The above shorter HgI distance and longer HgN distance represent a typical sample for the strong preference of Hg for soft donors (the iodine atoms) and weak preference for N atoms comparing to those reported in other Hg adduct polymers . The greatest angular distortion is also exhibited by the IHgI angle of 148.69(6)° and the NHgN angle of 85.5(5)°. While, the NHgI2 and NHgI1 angles (100.6(2)° and 102.2(2)°, respectively) are among the values of other polymeric adducts. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the azobpy ligands adopt an <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-conformation and the two pyridine rings are parallel. The distance between two azo nitrogen atoms is 1.26(9) Å.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Optical limiting effects</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The optical limiting effects of adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG5"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG6"></ce:float-anchor>. The peak fluence for <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan is about 1 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> in ns <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan. The transmittance is normalized to its linear transmittance at low incident fluence. The present two adducts, which have different polymeric skeleton, show a result that the optical limiting capacity of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is obviously better than that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. At very low fluence they respond linearly to the incident light fluence obeying Beer's law. The light transmittance starts to deviate from Beer's law of the linear response when the input light fluence rises to certain values with respect to each polymer. The values of the limiting thresholds are measured as 0.8 and 0.4 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> for adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with saturation fluences transmitted of 0.20 and 0.14 J cm<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>, respectively, from the optical limiting experimental data. These values are comparable to the values of many heterothiometallate clusters  Lower limiting threshold and saturation level provide greater safety margin for device protection. Previous study showed that the skeletal structure and constituted metal nuclearity have a strong impact on the NLO properties the clusters. Complexes with higher nuclearity or heavy atoms are expected to have favorable NLO properties . So as far as polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are concerned, the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 2 

The crystal structures of 2 are plotted in  . The compound is composed of 1D zigzag chains with each Hg bonded to two N-donor bifunctional ligands. The remaining two sites of the Hg atom are occupied by two terminal iodide ligands at a distances of 2.638(2) and 2.644(2) Å. To our knowledge, these values give a pair of shortest HgI lengths among HgI2 adducts. The interatomic distance between metal Hg and donor-N atom is 2.479(1) Å. The above shorter HgI distance and longer HgN distance represent a typical sample for the strong preference of Hg for soft donors (the iodine atoms) and weak preference for N atoms comparing to those reported in other Hg adduct polymers . The greatest angular distortion is also exhibited by the IHgI angle of 148.69(6)° and the NHgN angle of 85.5(5)°. While, the NHgI2 and NHgI1 angles (100.6(2)° and 102.2(2)°, respectively) are among the values of other polymeric adducts. In 2, the azobpy ligands adopt an anti-conformation and the two pyridine rings are parallel. The distance between two azo nitrogen atoms is 1.26(9) Å.

Optical limiting effects

The optical limiting effects of adducts 1 and 2 are depicted in   . The peak fluence for Z-scan is about 1 J cm-2 in ns Z-scan. The transmittance is normalized to its linear transmittance at low incident fluence. The present two adducts, which have different polymeric skeleton, show a result that the optical limiting capacity of 2 is obviously better than that of 1. At very low fluence they respond linearly to the incident light fluence obeying Beer's law. The light transmittance starts to deviate from Beer's law of the linear response when the input light fluence rises to certain values with respect to each polymer. The values of the limiting thresholds are measured as 0.8 and 0.4 J cm-2 for adducts 1 and 2 with saturation fluences transmitted of 0.20 and 0.14 J cm-2, respectively, from the optical limiting experimental data. These values are comparable to the values of many heterothiometallate clusters  Lower limiting threshold and saturation level provide greater safety margin for device protection. Previous study showed that the skeletal structure and constituted metal nuclearity have a strong impact on the NLO properties the clusters. Complexes with higher nuclearity or heavy atoms are expected to have favorable NLO properties . So as far as polymers 1 and 2 are concerned, the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.
